examples.title: Headings
examples.content:
HTML Headings (h1-h6)

Heading 1

This is a paragraph after h1. H1 is the largest heading.

Heading 2

This is a paragraph after h2. H2 is commonly used for section titles.

Heading 3

This is a paragraph after h3. H3 is used for subsections.

Heading 4

This is a paragraph after h4.

Heading 5

This is a paragraph after h5.

Heading 6

This is a paragraph after h6. H6 is the smallest heading.

examples.title: Semantic
examples.content:
Semantic HTML5 Elements

This is a HEADER element - typically for introductory content

This is a NAV element - for navigation links

This is the MAIN element - primary content of the page

This is a SECTION element - thematic grouping

This is an ARTICLE element - self-contained content

This is an ASIDE element - tangentially related content

This is a FOOTER element - typically for author info, copyright

examples.title: Figure Blockquote
examples.content:
Figure and Blockquote Elements

The figure element is used for self-contained content:

The blockquote element is used for quoted content:

This is a blockquote. It represents content that is quoted from another source. Blockquotes typically have indented margins to visually distinguish them from surrounding text.

- Anonymous Author

Another blockquote example:

The only way to do great work is to love what you do.

- Steve Jobs

examples.title: Definition Lists
examples.content:
Definition Lists (dl, dt, dd)
Basic glossary:
HTML
HyperText Markup Language - the standard markup language for web pages.
CSS
Cascading Style Sheets - used for styling HTML documents.
JavaScript
A programming language for the web.
Multiple definitions per term:
Firefox
A web browser developed by Mozilla.
A fast, privacy-focused browser.
Chrome
A web browser developed by Google.
Programming terms:
Variable
A named storage location in memory.
Function
A reusable block of code that performs a specific task.
Loop
A control structure that repeats a block of code.

examples.title: Text Indent
examples.content:
CSS text-indent Property
Pixel values:
text-indent: 0 (default):

This paragraph has no text indent. The first line starts at the normal position, flush with the left margin.

text-indent: 20px:

This paragraph has a 20 pixel text indent. Notice how only the first line is indented, while subsequent lines start at the normal position.

text-indent: 40px:

This paragraph has a 40 pixel text indent. The indentation is more pronounced, creating a traditional book-style paragraph opening.

text-indent: 60px:

This paragraph has a 60 pixel text indent. Large indents can be useful for creating visual hierarchy or special formatting effects.

Em values (relative to font-size):
text-indent: 1em:

This paragraph has a 1em text indent. One em is equal to the current font size, so the indent scales with the text.

text-indent: 2em:

This paragraph has a 2em text indent. Two ems creates a larger indent that still scales proportionally with font size.

text-indent: 3em (larger font):

This paragraph has a 3em indent with larger font. Notice how the indent is proportionally larger because of the bigger font size.

Negative values (hanging indent):
text-indent: -30px (with padding-left: 50px):

This creates a hanging indent effect. The first line extends to the left of subsequent lines. Useful for bibliographies and lists.

Percentage values:
text-indent: 10%:

This paragraph has a 10% text indent based on the containing block's width. Percentage indents scale with container width.

Multiple paragraphs:
Container with text-indent: 30px (inherited):

First paragraph inherits the text indent from the container. Only the first line of each paragraph is indented.

Second paragraph also inherits the text indent. Each paragraph starts with an indented first line.

Third paragraph continues the pattern. Text indent makes multi-paragraph text more readable.

examples.title: Line Height
examples.content:
CSS line-height Property
Normal (default ~1.2):
line-height: normal:

This paragraph uses the normal line height, which is typically around 1.2 times the font size. This is the browser's default and provides comfortable reading spacing between lines of text.

Unitless number (multiplier):
line-height: 1.0 (tight):

This paragraph has a line height of 1.0, meaning the line height equals the font size exactly. Lines are very close together, which can make text harder to read but saves vertical space.

line-height: 1.5:

This paragraph has a line height of 1.5, meaning 1.5 times the font size. This provides more generous spacing between lines and is often recommended for body text readability.

line-height: 2.0 (double-spaced):

This paragraph has a line height of 2.0, creating double-spaced text. This is often used in academic documents or when extra space between lines is desired for annotations.

Pixel values (absolute):
line-height: 16px (same as font-size):

This paragraph has a 16px line height with 16px font. Lines are tightly packed together since line height equals font size. Pixel values are absolute and don't scale with font size.

line-height: 24px:

This paragraph has a 24px line height. With a 16px font size, this creates 1.5x spacing. Pixel values give precise control but don't adapt to font size changes.

line-height: 32px:

This paragraph has a 32px line height. With a 16px font size, this creates 2x spacing. Notice how subsequent lines have significant gaps between them.

Em values (relative to font-size):
line-height: 1em:

This paragraph has a 1em line height. One em equals the current font size, so this is equivalent to line-height: 1.0. Lines are tightly packed together.

line-height: 1.5em:

This paragraph has a 1.5em line height. This provides comfortable spacing that scales with the font size. Em units are useful for responsive typography.

line-height: 2em with larger font:

This paragraph has a 2em line height with 18px font. The actual line height is 36px (18 * 2). Notice how larger fonts with em-based line heights create proportionally larger spacing.

Percentage values:
line-height: 100%:

This paragraph has a 100% line height, equivalent to 1.0 or 1em. The line height equals the font size exactly. Percentage is relative to the element's font size.

line-height: 150%:

This paragraph has a 150% line height. This is equivalent to 1.5 or 1.5em. Percentage values are often used for their clarity in expressing the relationship to font size.

line-height: 200%:

This paragraph has a 200% line height, creating double-spaced text. This is equivalent to line-height: 2.0 or line-height: 2em.

Side-by-side comparison:
line-height: 1.0

Tight spacing. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

line-height: 1.5

Normal spacing. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

line-height: 2.0

Wide spacing. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

examples.title: Overflow Wrap Normal Vs Break Word
examples.content:
1. overflow-wrap: normal vs break-word

Long words without spaces - normal won't break, break-word will break at character boundaries.

overflow-wrap: normal
Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious is a very long word.
overflow-wrap: break-word
Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious is a very long word.
word-wrap: break-word
Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious is a very long word.

examples.title: Url Breaking
examples.content:
2. URL Breaking

URLs are common cases where break-word is needed.

normal (overflows)
https://example.com/very/long/path/to/resource
break-word (wraps)
https://example.com/very/long/path/to/resource
anywhere (wraps)
https://example.com/very/long/path/to/resource

examples.title: Mixed Content
examples.content:
3. Mixed Content

Normal words wrap at spaces, long words only break with break-word.

normal
This text has normal words and Pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis mixed together.
break-word
This text has normal words and Pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis mixed together.

examples.title: Word Break Normal Vs Break All
examples.content:
1. word-break: normal vs break-all

break-all breaks at any character, even in the middle of words.

word-break: normal
This is a test with normalTextBehavior and words.
word-break: break-all
This is a test with normalTextBehavior and words.
word-break: break-word
This is a test with normalTextBehavior and words.
2. Long Words Comparison

See how different values handle very long words.

normal
Honorificabilitudinity
break-all
Honorificabilitudinity
keep-all
Honorificabilitudinity
3. break-all vs overflow-wrap: break-word

break-all breaks ALL words at any point. overflow-wrap only breaks long words.

word-break: break-all
Short words break anywhere with break-all.
overflow-wrap: break-word
Short words break anywhere with break-all.
4. Numbers and Technical Text
normal
123456789012345678901234567890
break-all
123456789012345678901234567890
5. Mixed Short and Long Words
normal
Hi there! Antidisestablishmentarianism is long.
break-all
Hi there! Antidisestablishmentarianism is long.
keep-all
Hi there! Antidisestablishmentarianism is long.

examples.title: Long Words
examples.content:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Word Break Test</title>
<style>
        body {
            font-family: sans-serif;
            font-size: 14px;
            padding: 10px;
            background: #f5f5f5;
        }
        .section {
            background: #333;
            color: white;
            padding: 4px 8px;
            margin: 10px 0 5px 0;
            font-weight: bold;
        }
        .container {
            background: white;
            padding: 10px;
            margin: 5px 0;
            border: 1px solid #ddd;
        }
        .row {
            display: flex;
            gap: 15px;
            margin: 10px 0;
        }
        .box {
            width: 120px;
            padding: 10px;
            border: 2px solid #e74c3c;
            background: #fdf2f2;
            font-size: 12px;
        }
        .label {
            font-size: 11px;
            color: #666;
            margin-bottom: 5px;
            font-weight: bold;
        }
        .narrow {
            width: 80px;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>



</body>
</html>

highlight

examples.title: Where Specificity
examples.content:
6. :where() Zero Specificity

:where() has zero specificity, so .override-test should win

Should be GREEN (class wins over :where)

examples.title: Is Specificity
examples.content:
7. :is() Specificity (Highest Argument)

:is(#high-spec, .low-spec) takes specificity of #high-spec

id="high-spec"
class="low-spec"

Text input:

examples.title: Focus Style Comparison
examples.content:
4. Focus Style Comparison

Compare different focus style strategies:

:focus only (green)
:focus-visible only (purple)
Both (orange/red)

examples.title: Usage Instructions
examples.content:
5. Usage Instructions

To test :focus-visible:

1. Click on an input with mouse - should show :focus styles only

2. Press Tab key to move focus - should show :focus-visible styles

Note: :focus-visible is primarily useful for accessibility - showing focus rings only when using keyboard navigation.

examples.title: Form Container Focus Within
examples.content:
1. Form Container with :focus-within

The form box gets highlighted when any input inside has focus.

User Information

examples.title: Nested Focus Within
examples.content:
2. Nested :focus-within

Both outer and inner boxes respond to focus within them.

Outer box (purple border on focus-within)
Inner box (red border on focus-within)

examples.title: Search Bar Pattern
examples.content:
3. Search Bar Pattern

Common UX pattern: search container highlights when input is focused.

🔍

examples.title: Multiple Inputs
examples.content:
4. Multiple Inputs

Any of the inputs being focused triggers the parent's :focus-within.

examples.title: Focus Vs Focus Within Comparison
examples.content:
5. :focus vs :focus-within Comparison

Compare: :focus only matches the focused element; :focus-within matches ancestors too.

:focus (green) - div can't receive focus
:focus-within (purple)

examples.title: Usage Instructions
examples.content:
6. Usage Instructions

How :focus-within works:

1. Click on any input field inside a container

2. The container (and any ancestor containers) with :focus-within will be styled

3. This is useful for form UX - highlighting the active section

Note: :focus-within matches if the element OR any descendant has focus.

examples.title: Has Specificity
examples.content:
6. :has() Specificity

:has() specificity = highest specificity argument. ID (#bar) beats class (.foo).

Has .foo only (blue)
Has #bar only (red)
Has both - #bar wins (red)

examples.title: How Has Works
examples.content:
7. How :has() Works

The :has() selector:

1. Matches an element if ANY of its descendants match the argument selector(s)

2. Multiple selectors can be comma-separated: :has(img, video)

3. Specificity = highest specificity of its arguments

4. Similar to :focus-within but works with any selector, not just focus state
